5.08.text:
-I have no selection process. 
The only thing that happens is

7.76.text:
they fall drunk in my lap,
and unfortunately I can't

10.93.text:
see what they look like.
Most people would be

12.58.text:
deterred by the red nose
and gray skin.

15.12.text:
Not a problem for me.
Bring it!

36.63.text:
-And then I had a taxi driver
ask me, just the other day,

39.89.text:
"do blind people marry 
other blind people?

43.62.text:
Or do they marry 
sighted people?"

45.96.text:
And I said to him, "Well, 
they only marry sighted people

55.75.text:
-Yes of course, of course...
Nice little match up

60.80.text:
It used to drive me wild. 
I have a couple of mates

63.69.text:
who are disabled, and 
people would walk up to us

67.24.text:
and say, "Oh isn't it nice
that you two are on a date?"

72.26.text:
-It's like we got a date passport

76.19.text:
-I do remember when I started
dating my current girlfriend,

78.85.text:

unbeknownst to me,

81.77.text:
behind the scenes, the 
question of the week was

84.33.text:
whether or not Rick's girlfriend

86.82.text:
which I found quite amusing, 
because I didn't even see it

89.17.text:
as a... you know... 
people are interested in this stuff?

97.06.text:
-I suppose, dating is definitely 
different. I definitely used to

104.63.text:
get more attention before I was
getting around in a wheelchair.

109.66.text: But it is... it's different now

118.54.text:
-I definitely feel like I have 
to take a hell of a lot longer

121.20.text:

126.26.text:
that I meet. Just because you don't

131.44.text:
so you want them to get to know you
as a person before you go ahead

135.91.text:
-But it's hard to get to 
get into that point, isn't it?

139.86.text:
People getting to know you
and not see the wheelchair,

143.35.text:
it's just that much harder, 
I think, in a dating situation

146.99.text:
because [inaudible]
but after a while, they just

155.22.text:
-He plays it pretty safe, 
and I can understand it,

158.17.text:
because, you know, you look at
a lot of movies and stuff

161.13.text:
out there make you [...] 
you know, people with prosthetics

168.76.text:
"Oh my God, and then she

and it's like Woah! 
Not ready for that!"

-Well the whole thing about

175.73.text:
do this thing where they 
"Catch each other's eye"

181.63.text:
So then people say, 
the odd thing people

184.05.text:
say to me is that 
I'm a snob, and I lose,

187.59.text:
because obviously I'm not

190.37.text:

and we have no idea, we think

193.82.text:
we're just looking into 
the lovely distance!

195.52.text:
-Oh yeah!
-And next thing, you got this....

197.57.text:
-...guy saying you've been
looking at them all night long

199.93.text:
-I go on a dating site now,
because I can be me,

203.11.text:
they can get to know me, 
and I can tell them about

209.98.text:
situations when they
say you've lied

212.45.text:
That's not what happened
actually, I just never told you

214.64.text:
that I'm disabled, but I am, 
before you meet me,

217.30.text:
I'm telling you now that I'm 
disabled, do you still wanna meet,

220.59.text:
after we've talked and 
we've got on really well?

222.64.text:
-And I get sick and tired
of some people I've heard,

230.20.text:
and it's just like "Oh, get 
over yourself, go out,

233.36.text:
meet some people, don't go 
on the hunt for a boyfriend!"

236.75.text:
-Yeah, exactly! They will find you,
if you're not constantly putting

243.45.text:
at the door, "I'm disabled, 
it's so hard to get a boyfriend!"

247.65.text:

250.04.text:
their personalities, and 
if some people go

253.62.text:
Oh, you know, some people go

258.48.text:
and I'm just like "really?
but inside I'm thinking,

261.72.text:
"is his personality as 
cute as he looks?

264.65.text:

and, if you're gonna live together,

267.28.text:
you're gonna need help 
with some things, and so

269.97.text:
after seeing that they're 
willing to go the long term

273.21.text:
and obviously they're willing
to help with those kinds of things,

275.97.text:
I think that kinda keeps
bad ones away cuz the

282.11.text:
-Cuz I don't flirt, that's the thing.
Mimi has this wonderful blinking thing

287.40.text:
which is fantastic, because 
it's so alluring

289.37.text:
-Do I? Oh!
-And the thing is, a lot of people

292.78.text:
would think that's a form of flirtation
-Really?

298.57.text:
-It's good though. 
I just don't flirt

301.38.text:
And a lot of people say to me
that they find me hard to read

305.80.text:
because I haven't learned 
through observation the

312.94.text:
-Once again, the process,
is junk falling on my lap

315.90.text:
-Mind you, being a gorgeous
singer, and great frocks

339.69.text:
-I don't have a problem 
with masculinity,

341.34.text:
for me, I think it was
more of an image thing,

347.23.text:
I'm not afraid to admit
that I'm vain, and that's

351.35.text:
regardless of me being 
in a chair or not, so...

355.14.text:
being in a chair did add 
a little bit of pressure

357.91.text:
-I think that in New Zealand
we've got very limited concept

362.18.text:
of what it is to be a man, 
to be masculine, and I think

365.79.text:
being in a wheelchair certainly 
does not fit that very narrow prescription

369.72.text:

as disabled my whole life,

now, growing up a bit more,

381.01.text:
with certain things

383.57.text:

385.60.text: I'm not afraid to do that.

-We've kind of hold up
Richie McCaw as this

410.78.text:
pinnacle of manhood, and

414.40.text:
quite narrow-minded about

417.60.text:
and accepting those, you know,
if you're not like a

431.30.text:
to prove his masculinity
with his friends you know?

433.89.text:
Tries to drink them under the table
and tries to push the limit,

437.55.text:
kind of thing, quite a bit
-Yeah

456.79.text:
-Oh my God! You're in a wheelchair,
you're pretty! Does not compute

yeah, I've gone on dates,

471.45.text:
actually get into

473.50.text:
and a lot of people would say,

475.99.text:
but that's being limited 
by your appearance

478.50.text:

was not as someone who was

482.61.text:
attractive or pretty.
I thought the "pretty"

486.34.text: aspect of me had died as well.

488.24.text:
-I remember actually going 
through my wardrobe, just after

491.43.text:
...I'd moved into a flat, and
now I was about to move home...

495.87.text:
so I had to clean my wardrobe,
and my sister was helping me,

499.99.text:
and she was saying, 
"Oh, you won't need this!"

501.50.text:
and she was finding all 
my nice underwear

505.75.text:
"Oh, you won't need these anymore!
You won't need this!"

508.16.text:
And also dresses and things, 
"you won't need this,

510.51.text:
you won't need that" 
And sort of leaving me

513.17.text:
the cotton bras and that

516.95.text:
So yeah, and it was funny
how we all had to change

520.69.text:
the way we thought, but of course
you're still gonna wear nice things,

523.93.text:
and nice underwear, and all 
those kinds of things, because

526.61.text:
you're still a female, 
and you still want those things

539.15.text:
-I just sort of dress the way I like to dress. 
I make a conscious effort not to look

544.53.text:
like I just came from an institution
-It still is a good look though

550.44.text:
-I have noticed that I did used to
probably get looked at more

554.44.text:
by males than I do now, and
I just find that a little bit sad

560.50.text:
I guess, because I can't change 
the way they think about me,

564.43.text:
and I can't be the girl that 
I was before my injury either,

566.74.text:
so it's just sad that they 
don't see that I'm the same person

575.50.text:
but, I'm not, so, yeah, 
I'm struggling with that

580.10.text: a little bit at the moment.

581.15.text:
-It's also a bit of a 
mantra that I do by myself

584.29.text:
and the whole look-good-feel-better
thing because if I feel really yucky

589.18.text:
on a particular day, and weak 
and tired and sore and I look in the mirror

592.92.text:
and I see that, it's like 
affirmation to me that I am sick

597.49.text:
and so, if I feel like that, 
those are the days that I'll

600.66.text:
actually push myself harder, 
get in the shower, put on some

603.33.text:
make up, put on my favorite top
with some color in it, and

606.73.text:
then I almost trick myself because
if I look in the mirror and I feel well,

612.47.text:
-We don't actually register 
any looks, of either

615.75.text:
approval or disapproval, 
so we're kind of like the

618.60.text:
sociological experiment, of 
"what would you wear if you didn't know

622.93.text:
whether or not it looked good or bad?"
You gotta trust your own taste,

625.70.text:
You gotta actually just move with your own... 
-With what feels good

629.70.text:
-Once you learn to love yourself, 
everything else falls into place,

632.17.text:
I mean, I'm getting old, 
I've just gone through menopause,

635.61.text:
I'm on the upper side now, 
heading down that hill pretty fast,

638.73.text:
and I've gotta hold on to the top
of the mountain, so I don't

642.71.text:
go down too fast. And I've realized now,
that I can enjoy life for whatever

647.90.text:
life is worth, and for 
however long it is,

650.26.text:
and I can enjoy it fully for 
who I am. And that is me.

671.27.text:
-The notion that I could
possibly have sex it's like... [inaudible]

683.85.text:
-So when I had my accident, 
I think it was really weird,

689.73.text:
it was like, all of a sudden, 
I was like, "Oh my gosh!"

692.26.text:
and I remember saying to the 
specialist - the registrar at

696.98.text:
the hospital- and he came 
to my room and I said,

701.28.text:
"Am I still gonna be able to have sex?
Am i still gonna be able to

703.34.text:
have children?" And he was like
"Oh! Uh... I'll have to get back to you"

711.37.text:
-I think people don't think about
sexuality of blind people,

717.70.text:
they don't think blind people
can cook, they don't think

720.56.text:
about blind people 
having sex either.

723.26.text:

we just do whatever a young guy does

729.23.text:

733.21.text:

741.45.text:
I don't wanna have to 
think about it, but

744.31.text:
now obviously my attitude's

747.83.text:
and we are, as I said before, 
still human.

-And so there is that 
weird thing coming through,

755.92.text:
there is a sense or, if you are
in a wheelchair...

759.87.text:
-Do you have sensuality? 
Do you have sexuality?

764.81.text:
Those things, which, 
I think must be a pain

784.28.text:
-I still would like to have children.
I'm aware that it's going to be

787.49.text:
a lot harder, much, much, 
much harder, I do see women

792.16.text:
pushing strollers around the 
place, and I'm like,

808.72.text:
-... a private obstetrician 
that we went to see

811.53.text:
and he ended up getting a punch

815.64.text:
cuz he said, "Can you leave 
the room a minute?"

818.06.text:
I was like "yeah, yeah"
When we ... [inaudible]

820.26.text:
He said, "I guess you are 
here for a termination?"

822.65.text:
I was like, "No, no, this 
was a planned baby.

824.26.text:
That's not what we're here for."
And he said, "Oh!"

827.76.text:
He was very very surprised, and
then he had a quick look at me

830.51.text:
and he said, "Everything 
seems to be alright,

831.57.text:
we'll put you under this
...maternity team"

833.74.text:
And he asked me to leave the 
room for a minute, and then

835.76.text:
he took Molly's father aside
and he said, "Look, you're

837.85.text:
a very handsome-looking, 
very successful man, you

840.07.text:
could have gotten a lot of 
other people pregnant, and

842.15.text:
you know, you probably shouldn't 
have done this, and he ended up

846.86.text:
flying through his glass window
in his reception area, and

849.97.text:
then we had quite a few bad 
experiences like that with

854.56.text:
professionals at the time. 
I don't think things are like

857.30.text:
that now, but there was a good 
lot of hard work from a lot of people

860.24.text:
in the last ten years that's
made things different.

863.45.text:
-I remember a friend of mine
had just had a baby, and

866.88.text:
she was disabled, and this woman
felt the urge to come up to her

870.31.text:
and go "Oh no, people with 
disabilities shouldn't have

873.62.text:
children" And it's like, what 
kind of license do you have

876.68.text: to ramble about that? You lunatic!

878.99.text:
-I've never even though about kids, 
I mean, I've gone off and seen a

882.95.text:
genealogist to see whether or 
not my kids would be born like me

888.32.text:
and apparently they wouldn't, 
apparently I'm just of a freak nature

893.34.text:
-When I was pregnant with Molly, 
it was my favorite thing!

896.12.text:
I've always been shy about my tummy,
and the whole muscular dis-trophy thing

899.68.text:
and it doesn't work well with 
my abs, and then I had this

901.64.text:
really big belly that was right
up here, and it was the first time

905.18.text:
I wore skin-tight dresses, 
because I didn't have to have

908.76.text:
rolls, cuz it's all so stretched out

912.98.text:
and really wonderful, and I've 
always heard things about scars,

916.34.text:
and impairment and being a 
disabled woman and things

918.87.text:
like that, and something magical

922.51.text:
this baby, and she was really, 
really healthy, and my body did

925.30.text:
exactly what it was 
supposed to do

949.30.text:
-The fictions are, people just don't 
believe that you are capable of

952.78.text:
raising your child, I even had 
family come to take sits when

956.85.text:
he was young, and Mike complained,
because he fell over, cuz he had

961.26.text:
cerebral palsy he was
extemely clumsy as a child,

965.57.text:
and he fell over by the heater 
one day when he was running in

968.87.text:
from the bathroom, and so all 
of a sudden [inaudible]

972.72.text:
you know, it was almost as if
I was a negligent parent

974.65.text:
-Parenting with a disability
has its challenges, believe me,

978.34.text:
I mean, it's great. I wouldn't 
change it for the world,

983.83.text:
I wouldn't change [...]
because he's a fantastic son,

986.88.text:
I think having a disability
opens you up to [inaudible]

992.65.text:
but it also means that you 
need more support, so there is

999.52.text:
-I've got this theory about the 
kids of disabled parents, that you

1002.56.text:
get all the humility, and lessons
and joy and empathy without

1007.03.text:
any of the pain or rubbish that
goes along with it. And a lot

1011.14.text:
of the kids of disabled mammas 
and daddies, that I've ever met,

1014.20.text:
and quite a lot, through my work,
incredible little people!

1018.35.text:
-Our kids would be the ones 
that help somebody that's struggling

1020.39.text:
at the supermarket or something, 
they drop something down,

1022.64.text:
[...] and she drops a whole lot of stuff down
our kids would be the ones that will

1026.23.text:
help pick it all up. They just 
get that "empathy" side of things

1030.03.text:
So I think it's good for them
in lots of ways.

1040.73.text:
-Communication is really
important in any relationship.

1043.63.text:
If he wasn't able to sign, 
I wouldn't give him a second look

1047.48.text:
-You tend to focus a lot more
on yourself because the first

1050.49.text:
thing that you have to do when you've
got a disability is organize yourself

1054.41.text:
so, it's very much focused around
your needs, and partners that aren't disabled

1060.54.text:
have found that quite difficult to 
deal with, because you're continually

1064.49.text:
having to set yourself up before 
you look at the relationship

1068.92.text:
-Communication's really important, 
like if she wasn't able to sign

1072.11.text:
with any depth, then the 
relationship wouldn't work

1076.79.text:
I mean, I never win 
any arguments...

1078.04.text:
-That's this thing, you know, 
you have to ask a lot of people

1081.25.text:
when you're in a relationship,
you are interdependent, you are

1083.46.text:
interdependent, you are reliant on each other, 
for emotional needs, for all sorts of things

1087.53.text:
-If I needed a lot more to center
around me, then I don't think

1091.87.text:
we'd probably still be together, 
but I'm sort of independent, so

1097.67.text:
I can cope with it. I mean, 
we've certainly had quite a

1101.88.text:
role-reversal in the practical 
aspect of things...

1106.74.text:
-There's a lot of people that would
tell you, "never have your husband

1110.14.text:
or wife as your caregiver" That's

1113.73.text:
It's bad. You're gonna mess 
up your marriage."

1115.31.text:
We haven't found it to be so...
-We've found the opposite, really

1117.82.text:
-Yeah, we're fine with if. I would feel a lot more 
comfortable, and so would Richard with him

1122.48.text:
if I get [...] getting me out of 
the shower, and giving me a hand

1125.24.text:
to get into tight jeans, and
we have a laugh about it,

1128.49.text:
-Because there is maybe a 
need for support in nature,

1133.16.text:
in some areas, to have someone 
who can give that freely

1138.28.text:
without feeling that, somehow 
they build up a resentment

1142.06.text:
around that, or, I don't know, 
I'm not saying this actually

1145.71.text:
happens, but this... 
Could explain why we're

1148.68.text:
both single at the moment
though, couldn't it?

1150.87.text:
-Sometimes partners feel that 
they put more into a relationship

1154.56.text:
than you are, because
you can't do the physical things

1157.77.text:
that they do, so I think that
can be quite affected, and

1162.15.text:
you quite often are gonna attract
women that are needy, or men

1165.52.text:
that are needy, if you're a woman. 
And they feel they've got a duty,

1168.76.text:
or they want to save you 
or something like that.

1172.22.text:
-You get these people
who are the over-carers

1176.03.text:
the over-protectors, that's the 
funniest thing though, because

1179.26.text:
I've pretty much never performed...
I've usually been the person who's

1183.30.text:
looking after and caring
-Well, yeah, I know, and

1185.45.text:
that's why I don't know 
the answer

1186.93.text:
-No, we have nothing to say
-What's your question?

1194.86.text:
Some people haven't managed to 
accept that you are, or realize

1199.84.text:
that you're still the same person,
so for me, I don't know about you,

1203.32.text:
but for me, a couple of friends
that were really close to me

1206.99.text:
just completely died away, because
they just couldn't deal with it.

1212.61.text:
I think they probably put off 
dealing with it, and then it just

1217.56.text:
-I must admit I lost a lot of 
my fiends, but I think that

1220.95.text:
when something like this happens
you find out that a lot of your

1224.36.text:
friends are only acquaintances, 
you know them through certain

1228.51.text:
sports, I have my golf and my cricket
--which I thought were-- friends,

1234.66.text:
but really, that were 
acquaintances, so you

1237.56.text:
come down to some
really good friends

1239.50.text:
-I didn't know what spinal cord injury was,
I didn't know what my future was gonna hold,

1244.03.text:
so I just kind of got on with 
things as I came to me.

1246.86.text:
Challenges arose and I chased after
them and it was great.

1250.93.text:
Whereas, I think it was pretty 
tough for mom and dad

1255.29.text:
but I think that seeing me change
helped them a lot as well.

1258.70.text:
-My parents are definitely
very worried about what

1261.35.text:
happens when they're not
there anymore, I think.

1264.82.text:
You almost do become a little 
bit childlike, for a while, don't you?

1269.02.text:
Especially after your injury, 
you are a dependent child again

1272.35.text:
and that's really hard, and you have to 
snap yourself out of that quickly

1278.82.text:
But you're always gonna be 
more dependent on your parents

1283.39.text:
-The relationship with my sister
suffered quite a bit, you know,

1288.83.text:
she's six years younger than me, 
and a lot of the spotlight came on me

1293.92.text:
at a time when she probably 
needed it and that was

1299.74.text:
probably quite tough
for her as well.

1301.58.text:
-My relationship with my dad changed
because I'd always been this really

1304.81.text:
independent person, and well now 
he was gonna do all these things for me

1309.11.text:
and he's got to, you know, 
I've become this, and I think

1312.47.text:
he really worried about 
the future...

1314.02.text:
-Look, there's no question that
there's lots of things we can't do

1317.40.text:
with our family, and sometimes 
Ann gets a bit, you know

1321.36.text:
but I don't worry about it. 
Ann probably does more, because

1326.81.text:
we can't do certain things, but we try 
to make for it doing other things.

1351.75.text:
-You know, independence is something
for me that I don't really think

1354.42.text:
twice about. It just is, I just do.
Growing up with a disability means

1362.64.text:
that, it just forms part of my existence,
I don't wake up every morning and go,

1369.31.text:
"huh, you know, should I get out 
of bed today, or I could just stay

1371.60.text:
in bed and just be dependent 
on everybody around me"

1374.22.text:
That's not even a choice. 
It's not a conscious thing.

1378.36.text:
I think it's just important to
get out there and live life.

1381.80.text:
-I think the most important thing
in my life is my independence, and

1385.37.text:
it's hard sometimes when other 
people come into my life, say,

1388.79.text:
a girlfriend, or something like that, 
you know, there's a natural instinct

1394.81.text:
for people to wanna help, 
I live my life without help,

1398.83.text:
a lot of the time I pushed 
away from it, and so sometimes

1402.24.text:
that does create a bit of
uncomfortableness.

1413.71.text:
-When you go with other people, 
it could be incredibly generous,

1416.46.text:
and people offer and pick you up
and that's fantastic,

1419.93.text: what happens though, is they are

1422.14.text:
actually in the power position, 
so you're always the one waiting,

1425.99.text:
you're always the one relying on 
other people, and even with taxis,

1430.77.text:
of course, it can be frustrating,
but I often prefer that these days

1434.74.text:
because I feel like I have 
some input into the time frame

1438.36.text: of when I get picked up.

1439.63.text:
-I don't really agree with the 
notion of being "fully independent"

1443.40.text:
I think the best thing ever
is to be in control of whatever

1446.48.text:
help you get because it can be
completely mental, and I do know

1450.49.text:
people who spend six hours a day
getting dressed because they

1453.82.text:
wanna prove that they can
get dressed on their own,

1457.40.text:
but you can't compromise other
aspects of your life in order to

1463.48.text:
-We both have a fear of going
places where you know you can't

1467.65.text:
get back from, on your own, 
and sometimes someone says,

1470.93.text:
"come to this amazing, secluded
place in the ...." And it's like,

1475.46.text:
I fear spots like that
-I can't walk back from the shore!

1481.78.text:
-She's rarely ever been defeated 
by something, there's always been

1486.63.text:
a way of doing everything, 
really, hasn't it?

1489.20.text:
Apart from undoing buttons...
-Yes, and doing the monkey bus,

1495.37.text: tying my laces, and tying my hair...

1504.38.text:
-Even when you're dependent, 
there is so much strength in

1508.89.text:
vulnerability, because at least 
you're actually admitting that

1512.17.text:
"this is what I need" and the
weakest position is when people

1515.10.text:
actually don't know
what they need.

1516.85.text:
-'Cause don't forget that 
we're all dependent, to an extent

1519.49.text:
that nobody knows complete, 
independence, so if you can

1522.89.text:
be in control of whatever 
help you get, and know where it's

1526.69.text:
coming from, I think that's the best
notion; independence is important

1532.50.text:
to me, but realistic independence 
is even more important.
